chapter.block: The Harbarthsljoth is found complete in the Codex Regius, where it follows the Skirnismol, and from the fourth line of stanza 19 to the end of the poem in the Arnamagnæan Codex, of which it occupies the first page and a half.

The poem differs sharply from those which precede it in the Codex Regius, both in metrical form and in spirit. It is, indeed, the most nearly formless of all the Eddic poems. The normal metre is the Malahattr (cf. General Introduction, where an example is given). The name of this verse-form means “in the manner of conversation,” and the Harbarthsljoth's verse fully justifies the term. The Atli poems exemplify the conventional use of Malahattr, but in the Harbarthsljoth the form is used with extraordinary freedom, and other metrical forms are frequently employed. A few of the speeches of which the poem is composed cannot be twisted into any known Old Norse metre, and appear to be simply prose.

How far this confusion is due to interpolations and faulty transmission of the original poem is uncertain. Finnur Jonsson has attempted a wholesale purification of the poem, but his arbitrary condemnation of words, lines, and entire stanzas as spurious is quite unjustified by any positive evidence. I have accepted Mogk's theory that the author was “a first-rate psychologist, but a poor poet,” and have translated the poem as it stands in the manuscripts. I have preserved the metrical confusion of the original by keeping throughout so far as possible to the metres found in the poem; if the rhythm of the translation is often hard to catch, the difficulty is no less with the original Norse.

The poem is simply a contest of abuse, such as the early Norwegian and Icelander delighted in, the opposing figures being Thor and Othin, the latter appearing in the disguise of the ferryman Harbarth. Such billingsgate lent itself readily to changes, interpolations and omissions, and it is little wonder that the poem is chaotic. It consists mainly of boasting and of references, often luckily obscure, to disreputable events in the life of one or the other of the disputants. Some editors have sought to read a complex symbolism into it, particularly by representing it as a contest between the noble or warrior class (Othin) and the peasant (Thor). But it seems a pity to take such a vigorous piece of broad farce too seriously.

Verse-form, substance, and certain linguistic peculiarities, notably the suffixed articles, point to a relatively late date (eleventh century) for the poem in its present form. Probably it had its origin in the early days, but its colloquial nature and its vulgarity made it readily susceptible to changes.

Owing to the chaotic state of the text, and the fact that none of the editors or commentators have succeeded in improving it much, I have not in this case attempted to give all the important emendations and suggestions. The stanza-divisions are largely arbitrary.

block.label: introduction
block.original:
Þōrr fōr ōr austrvegi ok kom at sundi einu; ǫþrum megum sundsins var ferjukarlinn meþ skipit.
Þōrr kallaþi:
block.translation:
Thor was on his way back from a journey in the East, and came to a sound; on the other side of the sound was a ferryman with a boat.
Thor called out:
block.comment: Harbarth (“Gray-Beard”): Othin. On the nature of the prose notes found in the manuscripts, cf. Grimnismol, introduction. Thor: the journeys of the thunder-god were almost as numerous as those of Othin; cf. Thrymskvitha and Hymiskvitha. Like the Robin Hood of the British ballads, Thor was often temporarily worsted, but always managed to come out ahead in the end. His “Journey in the East” is presumably the famous episode, related in full by Snorri, in the course of which he en countered the giant Skrymir, and in the house of Utgartha-Loki lifted the cat which turned out to be Mithgarthsorm. The Hymiskvitha relates a further incident of this journey.

block.original: “Hverr es sā sveinn sveina,es stendr fyr sundit handan?”
block.translation: “Who is the fellow yonder,on the farther shore of the sound?”

block.original: “Hverr es sā karl karla,es kallar of vāginn?”
block.translation: “What kind of a peasant is yon,that calls o'er the bay?”
block.comment: The superscriptions to the speeches are badly confused in the manuscripts, but editors have agreed fairly well as to where they belong.

block.original:
“Ferþu mik of sundit!fø̄þik þik ā morgin:
meis hefk ā baki,verþra matr enn betri.
Āt ek ī hvīlþ,āþr ek heiman fōr,
sildr ok hafra:saþr emk enn þess.”
block.comment: From the fact that in Regius line 3 begins with a capital letter, it is possible that lines 3–4 constitute the ferryman's reply, with something lost before stanza 4.

block.original:
“Ārligum verkum hrōsar þū verþinum;veiztattu fyrir gǫrla:
dōpr eru þīn heimkynni,dauþ hykk at þīn mōþir sē.”
block.translation:
“Of thy morning feats art thou proud,but the future thou knowest not wholly;
Doleful thine home-coming is:thy mother, me thinks, is dead.”
block.comment: Thy mother: Jorth (Earth).

block.original:
“Þat segir þū nū,es hverjum þykkir
mest at vita,at mīn mōþir dauþ sē.”
block.translation:
“Now hast thou saidwhat to each must seem
The mightiest grief,that my mother is dead.”
block.comment: Some editors assume a lacuna after this stanza.

Three good dwellings: this has been generally assumed to mean three separate establishments, but it may refer simply to the three parts of a single farm, the dwelling proper, the cattle barn and the storehouse; i.e., Thor is not even a respectable peasant.

block.original:
“Stȳrþu hingat eikjunni!ek mun þēr stǫþna kenna;
eþa hverr ā skipites þū heldr viþ landit?”
block.translation:
“Steer thou hither the boat;the landing here shall I show thee;
But whose the craftthat thou keepest on the shore?”

block.original:
“Hildolfr sā heitir,es mik halda baþ,
rekkr enn rāþsvinni,es bȳr ī Rāþseyjarsundi;
baþat hann hlennimenn flytjaeþa hrossa þjōfa,
gōþa einaok þās ek gǫrva kunna.
Segþu til nafns þīns,ef þū vill of sundit fara.”
block.translation:
“Hildolf is hewho bade me have it,
A hero wise;his home is at Rathsey's sound.
He bade me no robbers to steer,nor stealers of steeds,
But worthy men,and those whom well do I know.
Say now thy name,if over the sound thou wilt fare.”

block.original:
“Segja munk til nafns mīns,þōt ek sekr seak,
ok til alls øþlis:ek em Ōþins sunr,
Meila brōþir,en Magna faþir,
þrūþvaldr goþa;viþ Þōr knāttu hēr dø̄ma.
Hins viljak nū spyrja,hvat þū heitir.”
block.translation:
“My name indeed shall I tell,though in danger I am,
And all my race;I am Othin's son,
Meili's brother,and Magni's father,
The strong one of the gods;with Thor now speech canst thou get.
And now would I knowwhat name thou hast.”
block.comment: In danger: Thor is “sekr,” i.e., without the protection of any law, so long as he is in the territory of his enemies, the giants. Meili: a practically unknown son of Othin, mentioned here only in the Edda. Magni: son of Thor and the giantess Jarnsaxa; after Thor's fight with Hrungnir (cf. stanza 14, note) Magni, though but three days old, was the only one of the gods strong enough to lift the dead giant's foot from Thor's neck. After rescuing his father, Magni said to him: “There would have been little trouble, father, had I but come sooner; I think I should have sent this giant to hell with my fist if I had met him first.” Magni and his brother, Mothi, inherit Thor's hammer.

block.original: “Hārbarþr ek heiti,hylk of nafn sjaldan.”
block.translation: “Harbarth am I,and seldom I hide my name.”

block.original: “Hvat skaltu of nafn hylja,nema þū sakar eigir?”
block.translation: “Why shouldst thou hide thy name,if quarrel thou hast not?”

block.original:
“En þōt ek sakar eiga,fyr slīkum sem þū est
munk forþa þōfjǫrvi mīnu,
nema ek feigr sē.”
block.translation:
“And though I had a quarrel,from such as thou art
Yet none the lessmy life would I guard,
Unless I be doomed to die.”
block.comment: This stanza is hopelessly confused as to form, but none of the editorial rearrangements have materially altered the meaning. Doomed to die: the word “feigr” occurs constantly in the Old Norse poems and sagas; the idea of an inevitable but unknown fate seems to have been practically universal through out the pre-Christian period. On the concealment of names from enemies, cf. Fafnismol, prose after stanza 1.

block.original:
“Harm ljōtanhykk mēr ī þvī vesa,
at vaþa of vāginn til þīnok vǣta ǫgur minn;
skyldak launa kǫgursveini þīnumkanginyrþi,
ef ek komumk of sundit.”
block.translation:
“Great trouble, methinks,would it be to come to thee,
To wade the waters across,and wet my middle;
Weakling, well shall I paythy mocking words,
if across the sound I come.”
block.comment: This stanza, like the preceding one, is peculiarly chaotic in the manuscript, and has been variously emended.

block.original:
“Hēr munk standaok þīn heþan bīþa;
fanntattu mann enn harþaraat Hrungni dauþan.”
block.translation:
“Here shall I standand await thee here;
Thou hast found since Hrungnir diedno fiercer man.”
block.comment: Hrungnir: this giant rashly wagered his head that his horse, Gullfaxi, was swifter than Othin's Sleipnir. In the race, which Hrungnir lost, he managed to dash uninvited into the home of the gods, where he became very drunk. Thor ejected him, and accepted his challenge to a duel. Hrungnir, terrified, had a helper made for him in the form of a dummy giant nine miles high and three miles broad. Hrungnir himself had a three-horned heart of stone and a head of stone; his shield was of stone and his weapon was a grindstone. But Thjalfi, Thor's servant, told him the god would attack him out of the ground, wherefore Hrungnir laid down his shield and stood on it. The hammer Mjollnir shattered both the grindstone and Hrungnir's head, but part of the grindstone knocked Thor down, and the giant fell with his foot on Thor's neck (cf. note on stanza 9). Meanwhile Thjalfi dispatched the dummy giant without trouble.

block.original:
“Hins vildu nū geta,es vit Hrungnir deildum,
sā enn stōrūþgi jǫtunn,es ōr steini vas hǫfuþit ā;
þō lētk hann fallaok fyrir hnīga.
Hvat vanntu þā meþan, Hārbarþr?”
block.translation:
“Fain art thou to tellhow with Hrungnir I fought,
The haughty giant,whose head of stone was made;
And yet I felled him,and stretched him before me.
What, Harbarth, didst thou the while?”

block.original:
“Vask meþ Fjǫlvarifimm vetr alla
ī eyju þeiries Algrø̄n heitir;
vega vēr þar knǭttumok val fella,
margs at freista,mans at kosta.”
block.translation:
“Five full winterswith Fjolvar was I,
And dwelt in the islethat is Algrön called;
There could we fight,and fell the slain,
Much could we seek,and maids could master.”
block.comment: Fjolvar: not elsewhere mentioned in the poems; perhaps the father of the “seven sisters” referred to in stanza 18. Algrön: “The All-Green”: not mentioned elsewhere in the Edda.

block.original: “Hversu snūnuþu yþr konur yþrar?”
block.translation: “How won ye success with your women?”
block.comment: Thor is always eager for stories of this sort; cf. stanzas 31 and 33.

block.original:
“Sparkar ǭttum vēr konur,ef oss at spǫkum yrþi;
horskar ǭttum vēr konur,ef oss hollar vǣri:
þǣr ōr sandisīma undu
ok grund ōr dalidjūpum grōfu.
Varþk þeim einn ǫllumøfri at rǭþum,
hvīldak hjāþeim systrum sjau
ok hafþak geþþeira allt ok gaman.
Hvat vanntu þā meþan, Þōrr?”
block.translation:
“Lively women we had,if they wise for us were;
Wise were the women we had,if they kind for us were;
For ropes of sandthey would seek to wind,
And the bottom to digfrom the deepest dale.
Wiser than allin counsel I was,
And there I sleptby the sisters seven,
And joy full greatdid I get from each.
What, Thor, didst thou the while?”

block.original:
“Ek drap Þjaza,enn þrūþmōþga jǫtun,
upp ek varp augumAlvalda sunar
ā þann enn heiþa himin;
þau eru merki mestminna verka,
þaus allir menn sīþan of sē.
Hvat vanntu meþan, Hārbarþr?”
block.translation:
“Thjazi I felled,the giant fierce,
And I hurled the eyesof Alvaldi's son
To the heavens hot above;
Of my deeds the mightiestmarks are these,
That all men since can see.
What, Harbarth, didst thou the while?”
block.comment: Thjazi: this giant, by a trick, secured possession of the goddess Ithun and her apples (cf. Skirnismol, 19, note), and carried her off into Jotunheim. Loki, through whose fault she had been betrayed, was sent after her by the gods. He went in Freyja's “hawk's-dress” (cf. Thrymskvitha, 3), turned Ithun into a nut, and flew back with her. Thjazi, in the shape of an eagle, gave chase. But the gods kindled a fire which burnt the eagle's wings, and then they killed him. Snorri's prose version does not attribute this feat particularly to Thor. Thjazi's daughter was Skathi, whom the gods permitted to marry Njorth as a recompense for her father's death. Alvaldi: of him we know only that he was the father of Thjazi, Ithi and Gang, who divided his wealth, each taking a mouthful of gold. The name is variously spelled. It is not known which stars were called “Thjazi's Eyes.” In the middle of line 4 begins the fragmentary version of the poem found in the Arnamagnæan Codex.

block.original:
“Miklar manvēlarek hafþa viþ myrkriþur,
þās ek vēlta þǣr frā verum;
harþan jǫtunhugþak Hlēbarþ vesa:
gaf hann mēr gambantein,
en ek vēlta hann ōr viti.”
block.translation:
“Much love-craft I wroughtwith them who ride by night,
When I stole them by stealth from their husbands;
A giant hardwas Hlebarth, methinks:
His wand he gave me as gift,
And I stole his wits away.”
block.comment: Riders by night: witches, who were supposed to ride on wolves in the dark. Nothing further is known of this adventure.

block.original: “Illum huga launaþir þū þā gōþar gjafar.”
block.translation: “Thou didst repay good gifts with evil mind.”

block.original:
“Þat hefr eikes af annarri skefr:
of sik es hverr ī slīku.
Hvat vanntu meþan, Þōrr?”
block.comment: The oak, etc.: this proverb is found elsewhere (e.g., Grettissaga) in approximately the same words. Its force is much like our “to the victor belong the spoils.”

block.original:
“Ek vas austrok jǫtna barþak
brūþir bǫlvīsares til bjargs gengu:
mikil mundi ǣtt jǫtna,ef allir lifþi,
vǣtr mundi mannaund miþgarþi.
Hvat vanntu meþan, Hārbarþr?”
block.comment: Thor killed no women of the giants' race on the “journey to the East” so fully described by Snorri, his great giant-killing adventure being the one narrated in the Thrymskvitha.

block.original:
“Vask ā Vallandiok vīgum fylgþak,
attak jǫfrum,en aldri sǣttak.
Ōþinn ā jarlaþās ī val falla,
en Þōrr ā þrǣla kyn.”
block.translation:
“In Valland I was,and wars I raised,
Princes I angered,and peace brought never;
The noble who fallin the fight hath Othin,
And Thor hath the race of the thralls.”
block.comment: Valland: this mythical place (“Land of Slaughter”) is elsewhere mentioned, but not further characterised; cf. prose introduction to Völundarkvitha, and Helreith Brynhildar, 2. On the bringing of slain heroes to Othin, cf. Voluspo, 31 and note, and, for a somewhat different version, Grimnismol, 14. Nowhere else is it indicated that Thor has an asylum for dead peasants.

block.original:
“Ōjafnt skiptaes þū mundir meþ ǭsum liþi,
ef þū ǣttir vilgi mikils vald.”
block.translation:
“Unequal giftsof men wouldst thou give to the gods,
If might too much thou shouldst have.”

block.original:
“Þōrr ā afl ø̄rit,en etki hjarta:
af hrǣzlu ok hugbleyþivas þēr ī hanzka troþit
[ok þōttiska þū þā Þōrr vesa;]
hvārki þū þā þorþirfyr hrǣzlu þinni
fīsa nē hnjōsa,svāt Fjalarr heyrþi.”
block.comment: The reference here is to one of the most familiar episodes in Thor's eastward journey. He and his companions came to a house in the forest, and went in to spend the night. Being disturbed by an earthquake and a terrific noise, they all crawled into a smaller room opening from the main one. In the morning, however, they discovered that the earthquake had been occasioned by the giant Skrymir's lying down near them, and the noise by his snoring. The house in which they had taken refuge was his glove, the smaller room being the thumb. Skrymir was in fact Utgartha-Loki himself. That he is in this stanza called Fjalar (the name occurs also in Hovamol, 14) is probably due to a confusion of the names by which Utgartha-Loki went. Loki taunts Thor with this adventure in Lokasenna, 60 and 62, line 3 of this stanza being perhaps interpolated from Lokasenna, 60, 4.

block.original:
“Hārbarþr enn ragi!ek munda þik ī hel drepa,
ef ek mǣtta seilask of sund.”
block.translation:
“Thou womanish Harbarth,to hell would I smite thee straight,
Could mine arm reach over the sound.”

block.original:
“Hvat skyldir þū of sund seilask,es sakar'u alls øngvar?
Hvat vanntu þā, Þōrr?”
block.translation:
“Wherefore reach over the sound,since strife we have none?
What, Thor, didst thou do then?”

block.original:
“Ek vas austrok ǭna varþak,
þās mik sōttuþeir Svārangs synir;
grjōti þeir mik bǫrþu,gagni urþu þeir þō lītt fegnir,
urþu þeir mik fyrrifriþar at biþja.
Hvat vanntu þā meþan, Hārbarþr?”
block.comment: The river: probably Ifing, which flows between the land of the gods and that of the giants; cf. Vafthruthnismol, 16. Sons of Svarang: presumably the giants; Svarang is not else where mentioned in the poems, nor is there any other account of Thor's defense of the passage.

block.original:
“Ek vas austrok viþ einhverja dø̄mþak,
lēk ek viþ ena līnhvītuok launþing hāþak,
gladdak ena gollbjǫrtu,gamni mǣr unþi.”
block.comment: Othin's adventures of this sort were too numerous to make it possible to identify this particular person. By stealth: so the Arnamagnæan Codex; Regius, followed by several editors, has “long meeting with her.”

block.original: “Gōþ ǭttuþ ēr mankynni þar þā.”
block.translation: “Full fair was thy woman-finding.”

block.original: “Liþs þīns vǣrak þā þurfi, Þōrr!at ek helda þeiri enni līnhvītu mey.”
block.translation: “Thy help did I need then, Thor,to hold the white maid fast.”

block.original: “Ek munda þēr þā þat veita,ef ek viþr of kvǣmumk.”
block.translation: “Gladly, had I been there,my help to thee had been given.”

block.original: “Ek munda þēr þā trua,nema þū mik ī trygþ vēltir.”
block.translation: “I might have trusted thee then,didst thou not betray thy troth.”

block.original: “Emkat ek sā hǣlbītrsem hūþskōr forn ā vār.”
block.translation: “No heel-biter am I, in truth,like an old leather shoe in spring.”
block.comment: Heel-biter: this effective parallel to our “back-biter” is not found elsewhere in Old Norse.

block.original: “Hvat vanntu meþan, Þōrr?”
block.translation: “What, Thor, didst thou the while?”

block.original:
“Brūþir berserkjabarþak ī Hlēseyju,
þǣr hǫfþu verst unnit,vilta þjōþ alla.”
block.translation:
“In Hlesey the bridesof the Berserkers slew I;
Most evil they were,and all they betrayed.”
block.comment: Hlesey: “the Island of the Sea-God” (Hler = Ægir), identified with the Danish island Läsö, in the Kattegat. It appears again, much out of place, in Oddrunargratr, 28. Berserkers: originally men who could turn themselves into bears, hence the name, “bear-shirts”; cf. the werewolf or loupgarou. Later the name was applied to men who at times became seized with a madness for bloodshed; cf. Hyndluljoth, 23 and note. The women here mentioned are obviously of the earlier type.

block.original: “Klǣki vanntu þā, Þōrr!es þū ā konum barþir.”
block.translation: “Shame didst thou win,that women thou slewest, Thor.”

block.comment: Thjalfi: Thor's servant; cf. note on stanza 14.

block.original:
“Ek vask ī hernumes hingat gørþisk
gnǣfa gunnfana,geir at rjōþa.”
block.translation:
“In the host I wasthat hither fared,
The banners to raise,and the spear to redden.”
block.comment: To what expedition this refers is unknown, but apparently Othin speaks of himself as allied to the foes of the gods.

block.original: “Þess vildu nū geta,es þū fōrt oss ōljūfan at bjōþa.”
block.translation: “Wilt thou now saythat hatred thou soughtest to bring us?”
block.comment: Hatred: so Regius; the other manuscript has, apparently, “sickness.”

block.original:
“Bø̄ta skal þēr þat þābaugi mundar,
sem jafnendr unnuþeirs okkr vilja sǣtta.”
block.translation:
“A ring for thy handshall make all right for thee,
As the judge decideswho sets us two at peace.”
block.comment: Just what Othin means, or why his words should so have enraged Thor, is not evident, though he may imply that Thor is open to bribery. Perhaps a passage has dropped out before stanza 43.

block.original:
“Hvar namtuþessi en hnø̄filigu orþ,
es ek heyrþa aldriin hnø̄filigri?”
block.translation:
“Where foundest thouso foul and scornful a speech?
More foul a speechI never before have heard.”

block.original:
“Nam ek at mǫnnumþeim enum aldrø̄num
es bua ī heimis haugum.”
block.translation:
“I learned it from men,the men so old,
Who dwell in the hills of home.”
block.comment: Othin refers to the dead, from whom he seeks information through his magic power.

block.original:
“Þā gefr þūgott nafn dysjum,
es þū kallar þǣr heimis hauga.”
block.translation:
“A name full goodto heaps of stones thou givest
When thou callest them hills of home.”

block.original: “Svā dø̄mi ek slīkt far.”
block.translation: “Of such things speak I so.”

block.original:
“Orþkringi þīnmun þēr illa koma,
ef ek ræþ ā vāg at vaþa;
ulfi hǣrahykk þik ø̄pa munu,
ef þū hlȳtr af hamri hǫgg.”
block.translation:
“Ill for thee comesthy keenness of tongue,
If the water I choose to wade;
Louder, I ween,than a wolf thou cryest,
If a blow of my hammer thou hast.”

block.original:
“Sif ā hōr heima,hans mundu fund vilja,
þann mundu þrek drȳgja,þat es þēr skyldara.”
block.translation:
“Sif has a lover at home,and him shouldst thou meet;
More fitting it wereon him to put forth thy strength.”
block.comment: Sif: Thor's wife, the lover being presumably Loki; cf. Lokasenna, 54.

block.original:
“Mǣlir þū at munns rāþi,svāt mēr skyldi verst þykkja,
halr enn hugblauþi!hykk at þū ljūgir.”
block.translation:
“Thy tongue still makes thee saywhat seems most ill to me,
Thou witless man!Thou liest, I ween.”

block.original:
“Satt hykk mik segja;seinn estu at fǫr þinni;
langt mundir þū nū kominn, Þōrr!ef þū liþ of fø̄rir.”
block.translation:
“Truth do I speak,but slow on thy way thou art;
Far hadst thou goneif now in the boat thou hadst fared.”

block.original: “Hārbarþr enn ragi!heldr hefr þū nū mik dvalþan.”
block.translation: “Thou womanish Harbarth!here hast thou held me too long.”

block.original:
“Āsaþōrihugþak aldri mundu
glepja farhirþi farar.”
block.translation:
“I thought not everthat Asathor would be hindered
By a ferryman thus from faring.”
block.comment: Asathor: Thor goes by various names in the poems: e.g., Vingthor, Vingnir, Hlorrithi. Asathor means “Thor of the Gods.”

block.original:
“Rāþ munk þēr nū rāþa:rō þū hingat bātinum;
hǣttum hø̄tingi,hittu fǫþur Magna!”
block.translation:
“One counsel I bring thee now:row hither thy boat;
No more of scoffing;set Magni's father across.”
block.comment: Magni: Thor's son; cf. stanza 9 and note.

block.original: “Farþu firr sundi!þēr skal fars synja.”
block.translation: “From the sound go hence;the passage thou hast not.”

block.original: “Vīsa þū mēr nū leiþina,alls þū vill mik eigi of vāginn ferja!”
block.translation: “The way now show me,since thou takest me not o'er the water.”

block.original:
“Lītit es at synja,langt es at fara:
stund es til stokksins,ǫnnur til steinsins,
haltu svā til vinstra vegsins,unz þū hittir Verland.
Þar mun Fjǫrgynhitta Þōr sun sinn
ok mun hōn kenna hǭnum ǭttunga brautirtil Ōþins landa.”
block.comment: Line 2: the phrases mean simply “a long way”; cf. “over stock and stone.” Verland: the “Land of Men” to which Thor must come from the land of the giants. The Arnamagnæan Codex has “Valland” (cf. stanza 24 and note), but this is obviously an error. Fjorgyn: a feminine form of the same name, which belongs to Othin (cf. Voluspo, 56 and note); here it evidently means Jorth (Earth), Thor's mother. The road: the rainbow bridge, Bifrost; cf. Grimnismol, 29 and note.

block.original: “Mun ek taka þangat ī dag?”
block.translation: “May I come so far in a day?”

block.original:
“Taka viþ vīl ok erfiþi
at uppvesandi sōlu,es ek get þāna.”
block.translation:
“With toil and trouble perchance,
While the sun still shines,or so I think.”
block.comment: Line 2: so Regius; the other manuscript has “ere sunrise.”

block.original:
“Skamt mun nū māl okkat,alls þū mēr skø̄tingu einni svarar;
launa munk þēr farsynjun,ef vit finnumsk ī sinn annat.”
block.translation:
“Short now shall be our speech,for thou speakest in mockery only;
The passage thou gavest me notI shall pay thee if ever we meet.”

block.original: “Farþu nū þars þik hafi allan gramir!”
block.translation: “Get hence where every evil thing shall have thee!”
block.comment: The Arnamagnæan Codex clearly indicates Harbarth as the speaker of this line, but Regius has no superscription, and begins the line with a small letter not preceded by a period, thereby assigning it to Thor.
